text: incorrect fuel used to fill up company owned truck migrated from legacy cairs incident #34425we were notified by project superintendent, that two labors attempted to fuel company owned truck p-1149 at the lay down yard. both employees stated that they did not see the gasoline or dieselsticker on the fuel tank and assumed it was diesel. after the truck was fueled the paint crew gathered their materials and drove to the row. once there the truck was not operating correctly and it shut off. onsite mechanic tested the fuel and determined that gasoline was inside the tank. the truck will be transported to the mechanic shop for further evaluation. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

cairs action raised to capture malaria irp actions migrated from legacy cairs incident #30328aftera second spike in malaria cases in the africa business (similar spike noted in 2015),a irp was called to review the controls in place around malaria. although the spike occurred in the main in equatorial guinea, the irp looked at controls around the region and hence the actions are raised at an africa level.the irp was held on the 20th april. a copy of the irp is attached for information.whilst there is no single root cause (as it is almost impossible to confirm)when these individuals were bitten, there are noted opportunities for improvement in the implementation of barriers and mitigations. these are noted in the immediate and root causes and associated actions migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

category: dropped object or material, hand or arm injury
text: wood employee got left thumb caught between jack stand and rollers. wood employee was setting up a large jack stand at the wood fab shop. employee raised the jack stand up to the desired height and held it in place with the ring at the base of the stand. the ring was not completely in place and the jack slid back down to the bottom. his left thumb was caught between the large roller and the base of the jack stand. he was wearing stallion welding gloves at the time. employee was taken to off site clinic for evaluation and was released back to work with first aid treatment.  supervision was alerted. they contacted wood hsse and the employee was taken to off site clinic for evaluation. employee was released back to work with first aid treatment.

category: slips & trips, knife incident, hand or arm injury, foot or leg injury
text: shrink wrap installer cut himself with safety knife whilst trimming away excess material  shrink wrap installer was trimming the excess material from a newly installed doorway on a containment, as the operative cut down the material the knife, which the operative believed to be a safety knife as it was issued from our stores, slipped and caused a laceration to his thumb on left his hand. the installer was wearing cut resistant gloves. the ip was escorted to the cumberland centre and assessed. the cut was deep enough for them to recommend the ip attend a&e as there was possible tendon damage. as the bleeding had stopped and was dressed the ip decided to return to the office to conduct d&a test, which was passed, accident book and statement completed, the ip was then sent to a&e where it was diagnosed as a deep laceration with no tendon damage and two deep stitches applied. ip returned to work next day for his next shift. ip reported to the faff charge hand, adrian kerswill whom is first aid trained, who dressed the wound and assessed that the ip needed further medical assessment, ip was taken to the cumberland centre.safety knife checked to ensure correct knife, it was a safety knife but not on the approved list, sent to site in error from the supplier. all shrink wrappers knives removed from the operatives and replaced with fish knives whilst investigation commenced.

bumped structure in the pipe rack employees was working in the power block area 3301 unit. the employee working from the 80ft jlg, and was coming up on the lift looking left to right as he was coming up as well looking forward. the employee stated he was about 35ft off the ground at the time and he bumped the structure about pipe rack above him. contacted ineos job rep, ineos safety dept., also amec safety department was notified.  employees was taken to the safety office and company policy and procedures were taken. also the jlg lift was red tag out.

wood team member received a positive covid-19 test result while working from home a wood employee experienced   symptoms associated with covid 19 and was seen and tested by her health care provider on january 16th 2021. on january 19th the employee received a positive test result.  team member reported the result to their immediate supervisor and hsse

category: lifting or moving loads, vehicle incident general
text: cp-2021-0105 pd fpcl; excavator counterweight contacted passenger side of lv operator was loading hoses into a utility trailer that was attached to a light vehicle. as the operator turned the excavator the counterweight contacted the light vehicle passenger side doors causing minor damage. work was stopped. canadian model followed. incident investigation initiated.

superficial abrasion to nose when hard hat contacted scaffold tube worker was performing an inspection inside west crane hot work a habitat when their hard hat came into contact with a scaffolding tube causing a superficial abrasion to the bridge of his nose.the worker reported the incident to their supervisor and attended the cuq medical centre for assessment.after having the abrasion cleaned they returned to normal duties without restriction. reported incident to operator and attended medical centre.

1 contractor workers was been detected positive covid-19 after rountine mass  swab test conducted at 3rd party clinic on 15th january  2021 routine swab test conducted at 3rd party clinic and 1 electrical contractor detected positive covid-19 .the third party tester had manage to call the victim and in the meantime the crisis preparedness and response center (cprc) under the malaysia ministry of health has been informed for further action. the infected person was isolated and quarantine . 1.informed the victim and advised him to isolate himself at his home. 2.crisis preparedness and response center (cprc) was been informed about the covid-19 positive case. 3.isolated the closed contact 4. conducted contact tracing for tier1 and tier 2 close contact . 5.sanitation and disinfection at site facilities and worksite. 6.send out the closed contact to rt pcr swab test. 7.the infected person was isolated and quarantine at the designated covid-19 hospital .

potential dropped object - hp compressor exhaust shims identified to be loose while carrying out repairs to the ac compressor exhaust securing bolts, the rope access team carrying out the repairs identified large stainless steel shims (1.4kg and a5 size) that were protruding from the support structure and were loose.  the shims were at a height of approximately 14 metres. the loose shims were removed from the steel work and no further pdo's were identified.  this was then reported to the operations supervisor.

wood (truck) #1.20.9946 was stolen from employee's house.  at approximately 6:00 am employee became aware that vehicle # 1.20.9946 was stolen from his house while parked in his driveway. one of the doors was left unlocked. estimated loss value (if truck was never recovered was $17,000 usd)  after truck was recovered, there was about $1,000 in damages to the interior. vehicle was reported stolen to the local law enforcement and recovered by the police within 2-3 hours.

conduit damaged by rigged load swinging into it.  a wood rigger and his coworker were assigned to relocate a 12” inch (30.48 cm) diameter, schedule 40, spool piece of pipe that was approximately 20’ feet long (6.096 meters).  the pipe was sitting on jack- stands at the time. the two workers attached nylon chokers to the pipe and prepared to make the lift. the operator’s view of the actual lift was obstructed, so the rigger was to signal the operator using 2-way radios. before lifting the pipe, the coworker assessed the configuration and intervened. the coworker told the rigger that the way he had the pipe rigged and the crane set up, that it would shift forward and possibly contact the corner of the structure. the wood rigger ignored his coworkers concern and signaled to the operator to continue with the lift.  the operator was not a part of the conversation between the rigger and coworker and was counting on the rigger to properly rig and signal the load. as soon as the pipe lifted off the jack-stands the spool piece (pipe) shifted forward and the nylon choker came in to contact with a 3/4" live electrical conduit. this caused damage to the conduit in the result of a bend. the electrical line remained within the conduit and was not compromised.  once the spool piece section was relocated and set on the ground, all work activity was stopped, and wood supervision was notified of the event.  worked was stopped immediately and conversation was conducted with all involved regarding stop work authority and intervention. then witness statements were taken by all parties involved.

employee complains of chest pains during fire watch duties. employee was assigned firewatch duties along the east/west pipe rack when he began to experience shortness of breath.  all work was stopped and employee was escorted to safety trailer, where he was evaluated by client site medical team.  at that time, the decision was made to transport employee to mainland medical center in texas city, tx via ambulance. employee was treated at hospital, released with instructions to follow up with a cardiologist.  employee was also given a muscle relaxer and a mild pain reliever. employee's symptoms are considered non-occupational.

ip suffered injury to left shoulder and cut to bottom lip whilst trying to stop scanning equipment failing during high winds whilst carrying out scanning activities on the pfcp platform the surveyor became aware that the high winds were about to cause the scanning equipment to fail. the ip through instinct went to grabbed the equipment to stop it from falling to the gratings and in doing so injured his left shoulder and cut his bottom lip as a result of the scanning equipment striking him in the shoulder and lip. ip stopped the job and made work area safe.ip reported to the medic for evaluation.medic advised that the ip was to return onshore for further examination of his shoulder injury. medivac has not taken place due to flights being cancelled as a result of bad weather.

smoke coming from coconut matting. at approximately 03:45pm on march 16, 2022 an employee alerted their gf to smoke coming from coconut matting  at pcs 8, section 1, row 8 about 50 yards from where the team had just ended their break.  the actual severity rating is a1 because no one was in the immediate area and the damage is less than $10k.  the potential severity rating is also a1 due to no potential damage over $10k. the gf immediately extinguished the smoke and poured water on the area(3 inches in diameter) as precautionary measure.  gf notified safety and site manager.  immediate stand down was held.  investigation protocols were initiated.

preventable, company vehicle, minor damage, no injury. employee parked in the parking lot of blake's, off of paradise hills road and universe avenue. employee was pulling out of parking spot, looked left, pulled out and didn't see the other vehicle that was waiting to get into the drive thru lane on right side. the front of my vehicle on the passenger side bumper impacted the rear drivers side bumper of the other vehicle.  incident reported to hse department when hse reached out to supervisor with notice of incident by donlen, our fleet management vendor.

a wood worker received a positive test result for covid-19 while on pre-embarking preparation to trident pce-1. the ip is asymptomatic. a wood worker received a positive test result for covid-19 while on pre-embarking preparation to trident pce-1. the ip is asymptomatic. the worker was kept in the hotel and will be sent home for a quarantine period.

while walking uphill, ee stepped on a clump of dirt causing his right ankle to roll outward and his foot inward. employee walking up hill after pulling 4/0 cable down the hill. employee traveled approx. 30 yds. when he stepped on a clump of dirt and or hard piece of clay, thick piece of mud approx. the size of a baseball and causing his right ankle to roll outward and his foot inward first aid administered

damage to steelwork during tower erection by helicopter on sunday 25/08/2019, wood ohl team were undertaking the removal of tower h66 and replacement of it with new tower h66r, this tower is a pl1 (c) d30 e30, and the new tower was to be installed on the existing foundations, utilising rotex helicopters (switzerland). the tower had the conductors removed prior to the helicopter operations taking place and backstayed to each side to allow space for the lift to take place. the existing tower was dismantled, the first flat panels were installed on faces b-c & a-d, and were backstayed to hold in place, the first spider on panel a-b was flown into position and the top bar was bolted on leg a, another linesmen was on leg b preparing to bolt the top horizontal. lower leg a was not bolted, and lower leg b was bolted. rotex were controlling all lifting operations via a two-way radio from a ground operative to the pilot, this had been specified as the means of communication for all lifts. the load was released prematurely whilst only two bolts were in place (top leg a & lower leg b). this resulted in the spider pivoting on the bars that had been caught and rotating through 90° and coming to rest on the inside of panel a-d. this resulted in two bars being bent, these bars were replaced with the old steel from tower h66 until new members can be fabricated. at no time was any of the operatives inside of the base of the tower. job was stopped and an immediate stand down was had.  the work team were re-briefed and  work recommenced - the building of the tower was completed. the incident has been escalated to a level 2 investigation  as of the 10/09/19.

foreign body to eye (non-work related) at approximately 11:00 pm, employee was awakened by a pain in his eye, he looked at it and noticed it was very red.  he then waited till the morning and came in for the site pa to examine the eye.  upon examination, debris was found, and the individual was taken to local optometrist for further examination.  the employee stated that he did not have an incident at work the previous shift and signed off on the jsa confirming that he did not have any injuries. this event is deemed as non- work related. employee was examined by the on-site clinic and referred to an offsite optometrist for further evaluation.

the ip was tightening a socket on a 2" pipe with a pipe wrench, resulting in a "pinch point". the ip was tightening a socket on a 2" pipe with a pipe wrench with his assistant. whilst tightening the socket, the supervisor was giving an instruction; the ip lost concentration and the assistant continued tightening the socket, resulting in a "pinch point", pressing the ip's r index finger against a secondary pipe line. hpjv was notified. ip was taken to the isos site clinic for treatment and returned to work. a work stoppage was conducted with the team and supervisor. contractor with hpjv jointly initiated the stand down with re-enactment of the incident and proposed correct method.

wood employees tested antigen rapid test (art) positive. wood employees conducted self -antigen rapid test (art) at home due to their mild symptoms. the test results were positive. self-isolation to be carried out at their residence as per moh guidelines. disinfection had been carried out today. they will carry out self- art after 72 hrs. to report to doctor if symptoms get severe

slip on external stairwell ip was on route to heli admin to check in for his de mob, he approached the external stair case to heli admin and foot slipped of the stairs, this causing him the lunge forward and graze head on the stair tread  ip visited the medic and wound was cleaned with no further action required

category: head or face injury, mechanical or equipment issue
text: failure of tugger winch control migrated from legacy cairs incident #34408during coil tubing clean –out operations under wopg 2622, personnel were in the midst of lifting coiled tubing injector in preparation for breaking out the bha (bottom hole assembly).tugger operator #1 was operating tugger adjacent to drill floor stairs, he had relaxed tugger line from its normal stationery position. the tugger line was supported by a snubby line which affixes it to tugger when it is not in use. the tugger line was slacked off in preparation for assisting breaking bha by picking up the manual bha tongs which were situated on access scaffolding .it was then indicated to tugger #1 operator that his tugger winch would no longer be required as it was decided to use tugger #2 for this operation instead.tugger #1 operator then pulled back on tugger handle to spool in the slack, at this point the operating handle became slack and tugger continued to spool in.tugger #1 operator attempted to put tugger handle into a neutral position, but was unable to do so as the handle was being “hampered” by something.the tugger continued to spool in and tugger operator #1 reacted by turning the air supply to the tugger off and pushing the emergency stop button, thus isolating it, but at this moment the snubby line parted and caused the tugger line to re-coil up into the derrick and into the crown sheave, where it came to a stopthe slack in the tugger wire came down onto the d/floor adjacent to injector & riser.no personnel were hurt during the incident, personnel were operating with a drop ‘red’ zone in place and this is vigorously enforced during coiled tubing operationswhen the snubby parted the end of the tugger winch wire would have been 10ft above deck level so there would have been no possibility of it coming into contact with any personnel. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

the employee complained of pain when breathing.  he was taken to medical for evaluation.  the case was determined non occupational. migrated from legacy cairs incident #34035on friday, june 9, 20-17 at 7:25 am at dow freeport b 9300 block of poly 5 an infinity construction employee complained of pain when breathing. he was taken to medical for evaluation. the case was determined non occupational. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

employee removeing cargo from helicopter compartment, wind blew door shut on tip of finger causing minor laceration.  employee was in process of attempting to remove cargo from helicopter cargo compartment. in the process of getting stuck latch open the wind blew door shut on the tip of employees index finger. minor first aid laceration.  first aid measures applied. employee remained on work facility.

wood employee tested positive for covid-19 wood employee (shift supervisor) tested positive for covid-19 via 2 x consecutive lfdt. this is understood to be a community transmission.  individual undertook self isolation period, as per government guidance.

left ankle injury employee walked down an embankment to a water well and stepped in a hole, twisting the left ankle. workcare was consulted and they provided self-care, first-aid advice.  no additional treatment required.

category: lifting or moving loads, vehicle incident general
text: property damage employee jerry hanks was in process of checking module installations driving through the arrays 2-4. while traveling south looking on both sides of buggy for any obstructions in pathway specifically the cab systems mr. hanks struck a thin messenger cable with the buggy resulting a torn messenger cable. safety stand down with all craft. immediate driving restriction between all arrays. incident investigation protocols completed. employee counseled.

category: slips & trips, foot or leg injury
text: fall on same level due to slipping  on or about january 8, 2015, an employee fell and broke her leg in two places when she slipped on ice in the parking lot.  this resulted in an overnight stay in the hospital.

fall through surface or existing opening, unspecified an employee was working from a ladder above a suspended ceiling. the employee fell through the ceiling to the concrete floor and suffered a broken clavicle and multiple broken vertebrae.

category: slips & trips, foot or leg injury
text: fall on same level due to slipping  a maintenance employee was chemically removing some walking lines from the floor of the overhaul area.  there was some paint thinner poured over the walking lines that were being removed.  the area was not quarantined off and the employee was walking across the area and slipped, fell, and broke his right ankle.

category: lifting or moving loads, hand or arm injury
text: struck by object or equipment rolling freely an employee was unhooking a trailer when the trailer started to roll. the employee placed a hammer in front of the wheels to stop it and the employee right index finger was pinched between the trailer and the hammer. the fingertip was amputated.

category: slips & trips, fall from or working at height issue, hand or arm injury, head or face injury
text: other fall to lower level, unspecified an employee was climbing a ladder. the employee slipped and fell to the concrete floor, suffering a broken right wrist, chipped teeth, and a broken jaw.

struck by discharged object or substance an employee was cutting 3/4" x 2.25" floorboards with a saw-stop table saw. while he was attempting to cut a plank, the board kicked back and struck his lower right abdomen. he suffered a perforated intestine.

category: dropped object or material, lifting or moving loads, foot or leg injury
text: struck by falling object or equipment, n.e.c. an employee had a long screw auger set on pipe stands approximately 4 feet from the ground. one of the pipe stands tipped as he was adjusting the auger, causing the auger to fall onto his foot and fracture it.

category: fall from or working at height issue, head or face injury
text: other fall to lower level, unspecified an employee was hospitalized after falling off a truck and hitting their head.
caught in running equipment or machinery during regular operation an employee amputated three left-hand fingers while operating a chop saw.

category: hand or arm injury, lifting or moving loads, dropped object or material, vehicle incident general
text: struck by object falling from vehicle or machinery-other than vehicle part an employee was lowering a 3-inch pipe used as a guiderail for a lift pump when the crane cable broke below the cable clamp and above the cable eye. the pipe became unsecured and fell on the employee, lacerating the upper arm.

struck by other falling powered vehicle on january 20, 2020, an employee was working under a semi-truck that was on a jack. the employee was changing tires and doing an oil change when the truck slipped from the jack and crushed the employee's chest.

caught in running equipment or machinery during maintenance, cleaning  an employee was clearing a jam in front of the wood sorter gate before the chipper in-feed conveyor. the jammed wood had pushed the sorter gate up to nearly the full-open position. the employee attached a chain-fall to one of the jammed logs. as the log was raised, the rest of the jam was relieved and fell on the conveyor below. the sorter gate then closed on the employee's right leg crushing it between the gate, a piece of wood and the surrounding frame. the employee's lower right leg was fractured.
overexertion involving outside sources, unspecified an employee was delivering a 46-pound parcel when she suffered a hernia. she was hospitalized.

caught in running equipment or machinery during maintenance, cleaning  an employee sustained an amputation injury to the tip of the middle finger on his left hand while clearing a jam on a global partition slotter, which makes slots in corrugated cardboard. the employee reached into an area 3x4" wide, 2' long while the equipment was running. the equipment was not guarded at the time, nor was it shut down or locked out.

explosion, n.e.c. on 7/26/2021 at 1:08 p.m., an employee entered a customer's residence to investigate a natural gas odor. the house exploded and the employee sustained burns to their hands, arms, chest, and face that required hospitalization.

caught in running equipment or machinery during regular operation an employee was feeding dough onto a conveyor when their smock got caught in the conveyor belt. the employee suffered a hand injury and was admitted to the hospital.

category: lifting or moving loads, dropped object or material, vehicle incident general, foot or leg injury
text: struck by object falling from vehicle or machinery-other than vehicle part an employee was performing a quality check on incoming materials on a machine's feed line. a nearby forklift operator was attempting to lift a two-tiered stack of cardboard for loading into the machine when the top tier fell on the employee. the employee's right leg broke in several places, requiring hospitalization and surgery.

category: lifting or moving loads, vehicle incident general, head or face injury
text: collision between a moving and standing vehicle, nonroadway on march 17, 2021, an employee was working in the bucket of a bucket truck when a box truck drove under the bucket and struck its bottom. the bucket turned 90 degrees and ejected the employee, who landed on top of the box truck and then rolled off it to the ground below. the employee suffered a head injury and was hospitalized.

caught in running equipment or machinery during regular operation a temporary employee's left hand became caught in a trash compactor, pinching and breaking a couple of fingers and lacerating the hand.

struck by dislodged flying object, particle an employee was making a 13-inch bushing on a vertical turning lathe. the lathe moved down and in, causing the chuck to break free and strike the employee's left ankle. it broke the ankle and lacerated the employee's left foot.

contact with objects and equipment, unspecified an employee was cleaning out a frac tank when a tube came into contact with the opening on top of the tank. the employee's right index finger was crushed, and the tip was medically amputated.

category: dropped object or material, foot or leg injury
text: struck by falling object or equipment, unspecified an employee was removing a pipe, which was about 1 foot above the ground, when the pipe fell on the employee's right foot and broke toes.

category: fall from or working at height issue, foot or leg injury
text: other fall to lower level, unspecified an employee had been stocking products in an aisle and fell from a ladder cart. the employee's left knee was fractured and dislocated.
multiple types of overexertion involving outside sources an employee was unloading a truck when he had a seizure during which he fell and broke his nose.
exposure to environmental heat an employee suffered from heat exhaustion while dismantling trucks.

other fall to lower level less than 6 feet an employee was inspecting finished lightbulb products in a cardboard box at an inspection station. the inspection station was on a work platform that is 33 inches wide, 8 feet long, and 9 inches high. the employee finished inspecting the parts in the cardboard box and turned to go get another cardboard box full of light bulbs. as she turned to step off the platform, she fell to the ground and injured her hip, requiring hospitalization and surgery.

other fall to lower level less than 6 feet an employee was repairing a 55-gallon stainless steel mixing tank from a six foot step ladder. he was positioned on the second step of the ladder when he miss-stepped and slid down the side of the tank. he was hospitalized for internal bleeding.

part of occupantís body caught between vehicle and other object in nonroadway transport incident the employee was operating a stand-up forklift and wanted to stop it. before it came to a complete stop he dismounted the forklift, then realized it was not stopping and attempted to jump back onto the forklift.  his foot and ankle got jammed between the forklift and a metal pole resulting in foot and ankle fractures.
fall, slip, trip, unspecified  an employee tripped and fell while wheeling an appliance out of a trailer, suffering a back compression fracture.

category: fall from or working at height issue, foot or leg injury
text: other fall to lower level 6 to 10 feet an employee was on a roof, hanging christmas lights along the edge. he fell off the edge, landing about 9 1/2 feet below with his heels on the edge of the sidewalk and the fronts of his feet in the grass. he suffered two fractured heels and, possibly, fractures to the left tibia and fibula. fall protection was not being worn at the time of the incident.

category: fall from or working at height issue, general injury, head or face injury
text: other fall to lower level 6 to 10 feet an employee fell approximately 7 feet from an elevated picker while picking an order from the second level up. he landed between the mast and forks of a forklift, suffering bruising on his left side, a collapsed lung, brain bleeding, and facial injuries.

category: lifting or moving loads, hand or arm injury, foot or leg injury
text: pedestrian struck by vehicle in nonroadway area, unspecified an employee was walking beside a moving large rubber-tired loader, providing hand signals and verbal guidance to the loader operator who was transporting a piece of equipment, when the loader tire ran over the employee's left foot. he suffered a broken left foot that required hospitalization and surgery.

fall on same level due to tripping over an object  an employee was cleaning a room with a mop. the employee stepped backward and their foot became entangled in the mop. the employee tripped and fell backward to the floor, resulting in a back injury and a hip contusion.

injured by slipping or swinging object held by injured worker an employee was cutting a palm tree with a chain saw while standing on an extension ladder. the chainsaw kicked back and lacerated his left bicep, requiring hospitalization.
caught in running equipment or machinery, unspecified an employee was working on a door hinge machine when they suffered a left index finger amputation past the first knuckle.
other fall to lower level less than 6 feet an employee slipped off the second step of a ladder while descending and fell to the ground, fracturing his left hip and requiring surgery.

category: lifting or moving loads, hand or arm injury
text: compressed or pinched by shifting objects or equipment on december 22, 2016, at 11:00 a.m. an employee was manually moving a snow plow blade on a parked forklift and caught his finger under the blade and between a fork on the forklift resulting in a left middle fingertip amputation.

category: slips & trips, fall from or working at height issue, general injury
text: fall through surface or existing opening, unspecified an employee was servicing an hvac system in a ceiling crawl space. as she was walking in the crawl space, she stepped on a closed access panel that suddenly opened. she fell to the ground below and hit a table, fracturing her hip.

category: slips & trips, general injury, hand or arm injury, head or face injury
text: fall on same level due to tripping over an object  an employee was doing a live broadcast at a car wash when she tripped on a cement junction box and fell to the ground. the employee sustained a nosebleed, a small cut on her nose, and a broken elbow.

category: lifting or moving loads, hand or arm injury
text: struck against stationary object or equipment, n.e.c. an employee partially amputated two fingertips while cleaning a deli slicer. ppe was not worn at the time of the incident.
contact with hot objects or substances an employee was pouring hot caramel from a bowl to a pan. the caramel spilled, causing the employee to sustain second and third degree burns to both hands.

direct exposure to electricity, greater than 220 volts employee was testing a meter with an 8-ft shotgun stick in an energized zone and encountered an arc flash. this incident occurred at approximately 8:00 am on january 12, 2015. the employee was hospitalized with 2nd and 3rd degree burns. the employee was authorized to be in the energized zone and was wearing flame retardant clothing, a hard hat, safety glasses and a high-visibility vest.

compressed or pinched by shifting objects or equipment an employee was trying to hook up a trailer to a truck hitch when his right index finger was pinched and amputated between the trailer hook and the truck hitch.

struck by object or equipment, n.e.c. an employee was using a pry bar to unjam a cage when a nearby forklift operator dumped a full chicken cage. the full cage slid and struck the employee, causing a pelvic injury.

transportation incident, unspecified an employee was pinned between a customer's truck and an alignment rack, suffering four fractured ribs, multiple bruises of the body, and a hematoma to the liver. the employee was hospitalized.

caught in or compressed by equipment or objects, n.e.c. an employee removed a rare earth magnet during maintenance activity in the corn processing operation. the magnet was placed on a table that attracted the magnet and his finger was caught between it and the table causing a partial amputation.
fall on same level due to tripping over an object  an employee was cleaning and sorting a toy bin. the employee tripped over the bin and fell breaking the right hip.

caught in running equipment or machinery during maintenance, cleaning  two employees were troubleshooting a conveyor in a feed mill. the conveyor caught one employee's coat and pulled his left arm in. the arm was lacerated and his index finger was partially amputated. he was hospitalized.

caught in running equipment or machinery, unspecified an employee was loading parts onto the read side of a piercing and bending machine when the machine was engaged. the employee sustained a crushing injury to her thumb.

fall on same level, n.e.c.  an employee was feeding boxes into a machine when one of the boxes tore. she was trying to retrieve the torn box from the machine's conveyor when she lost her balance, twisted, and fell to the floor, injuring her left hip and requiring overnight hospitalization.
struck against moving part of machinery or equipment an employee was using a planer when the employee's left hand contacted the blade, resulting in amputation of the left pinky and ring fingers.
caught in running equipment or machinery during maintenance, cleaning  an employee was cleaning a plate on the press and amputated fingertips.

part of occupantís body caught between vehicle and other object in nonroadway transport incident an employee was using a forklift to move a rolling cart with a spiral weldment. as he was pushing the spiral and cart, the forklift entered an inclined area. the front of the cart and the spiral started drifting/rolling down the incline. he put the forklift in reverse and backed up to get in front of the spiral and cart as it was rolling and then reached out with his right hand to deflect the cart's direction of travel. his right finger middle finger was then caught and crushed between the spiral and the roll cage of the forklift.

caught in running equipment or machinery during maintenance, cleaning  an employee was clearing out residual materials on a screw auger when his finger contacted the screw component that was turning inside the auger, amputating one-third to one-half of his right middle finger and severely cutting his right index fingertip.

compressed or pinched by shifting objects or equipment an employee was in an aerial lift preparing to install mechanical rigging onto a new power line when the fourth and fifth fingers of the employee's right hand were pinched and crushed between the aerial lift basket rail and the cross arm of the power line structure.
contact with hot objects or substances an employee's right hand was burned in a pan containing hot fry oil.

category: lifting or moving loads, vehicle incident general, foot or leg injury
text: pedestrian struck by vehicle backing up in nonroadway area an employee was standing on the dock talking to an employee sitting on a forklift. another forklift operator was backing out of a trailer adjacent to the employee and struck the employee. the employee suffered a broken right leg.

category: dropped object or material, lifting or moving loads
text: struck by falling object or equipment, n.e.c. an employee was moving a pallet of product with a power jack. after the pallet jack was removed from the pallet, the pallet of product became unstable and cases of product fell onto the employee, injuring one of the employee's ears.

struck by object or equipment, unspecified an employee was clearing out concrete from the inside of a 5-inch pipeline. a metal object that was being used to remove the concrete lacerated the employee's cheek.

category: fall from or working at height issue, general injury, head or face injury
text: other fall to lower level 6 to 10 feet an employee was working on an air conditioning unit while on an 8-foot fiberglass ladder. he fell approximately 4-6 feet to the ground hitting his head. the employee sustained four broken ribs on the left side and scrapes on the hands.

part of occupantís body caught between vehicle and other object in nonroadway transport incident an employee was hospitalized due to a laceration to the right foot which resulted from an accident involving a double pallet jack and a racking system.

exposure to environmental heat an employee had been sitting idle in an air conditioned 18-wheeler and then came into the office with symptoms of lightheadedness, dizziness, and slightly elevated blood pressure. the employee was hospitalized due to heat stress (dehydration, heat exhaustion).

caught in or compressed by equipment or objects, unspecified an employee was guiding a crane as it moved pieces of steel. the employee's right thumb was smashed between two of the pieces, suffering an amputation.

category: slips & trips, fall from or working at height issue, head or face injury
text: other fall to lower level 16 to 20 feet while spraying precast concrete from a scaffold, an employee slipped and fell 4 feet to a main scaffold and then fell an additional 14 feet to the ground, suffering a head injury that required hospitalization.

struck by dislodged flying object, particle an employee was cutting a cardboard core on a core cutting machine when the core spun out of the machine, striking the employee in the face and mouth. the employee suffered nose, sinus, and palate fractures.

category: fall from or working at height issue, general injury
text: other fall to lower level 6 to 10 feet on february 8, 2016, at approximately 1:00 pm, an employee working on an hvac unit fell approximately 8 feet into the return case of an air handler unit on the roof of the structure. the employee suffered vertebrae, rib, and scapula fractures, as well as a collapsed lung.

category: slips & trips, foot or leg injury
text: slip without fall, n.e.c.  an employee was building forms for a concrete pull box and stepped on an x brace. his foot slid down the brace and he severely rolled his ankle resulting in a broken tibia.

category: lifting or moving loads, foot or leg injury
text: struck by discharged object or substance while using a high-pressure power washer, an employee's right foot was impaled by the power washer.

category: slips & trips, foot or leg injury
text: fall on same level due to slipping  an employee was walking towards the receiving area entrance from the parking lot when they slipped on black ice. the employee grabbed onto an orange barrel to stop from falling and twisted their leg, resulting in fractures to the tibia and fibula.

category: slips & trips, hand or arm injury
text: fall on same level due to tripping on uneven surface employee tripped on a paver and fractured her wrist, requiring hospitalization.

compressed or pinched by shifting objects or equipment an employee was troubleshooting/changing a belt on an air handling unit in the office area. the machine was shut off. as the employee checked the tension on one belt, the right middle finger contacted the still turning motor and was pulled into the flywheel resulting in a fingertip amputation.
